user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_set_thread_name_:
```c
static int
MHD_set_thread_name_ (const MHD_thread_ID_native_ thread_id,
                      const char *thread_name)
{
  if (NULL == thread_name)
    return 0;

#if defined(HAVE_PTHREAD_SETNAME_NP_GNU)
  return ! pthread_setname_np (thread_id, thread_name);
#elif defined(HAVE_PTHREAD_SET_NAME_NP_FREEBSD)
  /* FreeBSD and OpenBSD use different function name and void return type */
  pthread_set_name_np (thread_id, thread_name);
  return ! 0;
#elif defined(HAVE_PTHREAD_SETNAME_NP_NETBSD)
  /* NetBSD use 3 arguments: second argument is string in printf-like format,
   *                         third argument is a single argument for printf();
   * OSF1 use 3 arguments too, but last one always must be zero (NULL).
   * MHD doesn't use '%' in thread names, so both form are used in same way.
   */
  return ! pthread_setname_np (thread_id, thread_name, 0);
#endif /* HAVE_PTHREAD_SETNAME_NP_NETBSD */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no uses of the Standard Library function memcmp in the provided code. The function MHD_set_thread_name_ only checks for NULL on thread_name and then calls various pthread set-name APIs (pthread_setname_np, pthread_set_name_np, pthread_setname_np with three args). There are no memcmp calls and no manual byte-wise comparisons of null-terminated strings in any branch. Therefore there are no code fragments in this snippet that need investigation for potential violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 (prohibiting memcmp to compare null-terminated strings).
